Article Title: 'Will respond at right time': Taliban's warning after Pakistani air strikes kill 10; vows retaliation
Article Text:
Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid

'Necessary Response At Proper Time': Taliban Vows Action After 10 Killed In Pak Strikes





The overnight Pakistani air strikes in eastern Afghanistan that killed 10 civilians Tuesday prompted the Taliban government to vow it would respond “appropriately at the right time. ”“The Islamic Emirate strongly condemns this violation and crime and reiterates that defending its airspace, territory, and people is its legitimate right, and it will respond appropriately at the right time,” Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said on X.'Nothing comes to the forefront except the failure and disgrace of Pakistan's military regime," he added.Mujahid, in a previous stament, said nine of the victims were children — five boys and four girls — and one was a woman. “The Pakistani invading forces bombed the house of a local civilian resident... As a result, nine children (five boys and four girls) and one woman were martyred” in Khost province.Pakistan’s military and government did not immediately commente on the air strike allegations.Other strikes hit the border regions of Kunar and Paktika, injuring four more civilians, AFP reported citing Mujahid’s post.A day earlier, two suicide bombers and a gunman attacked the Federal Constabulary headquarters in Peshawar’s Saddar area, killing three officers and wounding 11.Security forces quickly neutralized the attackers. No group has claimed responsibility, though suspicion fell on the Pakistani Taliban, or Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan, reported AP.Following the attacks, a Pakistani diplomat met with a senior Afghan provincial leader to discuss security concerns, just hours after the Peshawar bombing.The strikes follow cross-border clashes more than a month ago when Afghanistan claimed Pakistani drone strikes hit Kabul. A ceasefire brokered by Qatar and Turkey in October remains in place despite the latest reported strikes, with neither country issuing statements on the incident.Iran has also offered to play a role in easing tensions between the two neighbors.
Article Summary: Pakistani air strikes in eastern Afghanistan killed 10 civilians Tuesday. Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said nine of the victims were children. No group has claimed responsibility, though suspicion fell on the Pakistani Taliban. A day earlier, two suicide bombers and a gunman attacked the Federal Constabulary headquarters in Peshawar’s Saddar area, killing three officers.

Article Title: Bangladesh earthquake: At least six killed, several injured; visuals emerge
Article Text:
5.7-magnitude earthquake in Bangladesh triggers tremors across Kolkata, northeast





NEW DELHI: A 5.5-magnitude earthquake struck central Bangladesh on Friday, killing at least six people and injuring several, AP reported citing officials. The quake, which shook buildings in Dhaka and sent residents fleeing outdoors, was felt across several parts of the country and in neighbouring regions of India including Kolkata.Also read: West Bengal: Strong tremors jolt Kolkata; no damage reported yet The US Geological Survey said the earthquake occurred at 10:38 am, with the epicentre located in the Ghorashal area of Narsingdi district, about 25 kilometres from Dhaka, at a depth of 10 kilometres. Dhaka-based DBC Television reported that six people died in the capital, including three who were killed when a roof and a wall collapsed, and three pedestrians who were struck by falling building railings.Authorities said the tremors caused significant panic in Dhaka, one of the world’s most densely populated cities with more than 30,000 people per square kilometre. Bangladesh’s central region is typically less seismically active than the north and southeast, where interactions between the India and Eurasia plates make earthquakes more common.A separate update from ANI said a 5.5-magnitude quake near Narsingdi was felt widely across Dhaka around 10:40 am and also in parts of India including West Bengal and areas of the northeast.The USGS recorded the event at 10:08 am IST. As per the ANI report, “There have been no reports of casualties or damage so far,” though later official updates confirmed fatalities in the capital.Last month, Bangladesh recorded a magnitude 3.4 earthquake, according to the National Centre for Seismology. Experts note that shallow earthquakes can produce stronger surface shaking because seismic waves travel a shorter distance.Citing USGS figures, The Daily Star reported that a magnitude 4.0 earthquake releases energy equivalent to about 6 tons of TNT, while a magnitude 5.0 quake corresponds to around 200 tons. The energy rises steeply with each magnitude, with a 7.0 quake equalling nearly 199,000 tons of TNT and a 9.0 quake releasing about 99 million tons, comparable to roughly 25,000 nuclear bombs.Bangladesh sits at the junction of the Indian, Eurasian and Burma plates, which move several centimetres each year. The country is intersected by major faults including the Bogura, Tripura, Shillong Plateau, Dauki and Assam faults, placing it within 13 recognised earthquake-prone zones. Regions such as Chattogram, the Chattogram Hill Tracts and Jaintiapur in Sylhet fall within the highest-risk category.Visuals from Dhaka on Friday showed emergency teams assessing damage as authorities monitored aftershocks and structural impacts across the capital.(With inputs from AP and ANI)
Article Summary: A 5.5-magnitude earthquake struck central Bangladesh on Friday, killing at least six people. The quake, which shook buildings in Dhaka and sent residents fleeing outdoors, was felt across several parts of the country and in neighbouring regions of India including Kolkata.

Article Title: 'Yunus can't touch my mother': Sheikh Hasina's son slams death verdict; thanks India for saving her life
Article Text:
Sheikh Hasina (ANI file photo)

'Eternally Grateful': Sheikh Hasina's Son Thanks PM Modi For Saving His Mother's Life, Slams Yunus





Ousted Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina ’s son, Sajeeb Wazed, on Thursday alleged that country's interim leader Muhammad Yunus would not be able to harm his mother. He insisted that “Yunus cannot touch my mother and he cannot do anything to her.”His remarks come at a time when Hasina’s future hangs in the balance after a tribunal in Bangladesh sentenced her to death over alleged involvement in the deadly student-led uprising of 2024. The tribunal linked her to the violent crackdown that preceded her ouster. Chief adviser and interim leader Bangladesh, Muhammad Yunus welcomed the verdict, insisting that no one is above the law.Speaking to IANS, Wazed said: “They will not be able to kill her, but they will execute the verdict. First of all, they can’t get her. And once there is a rule of law, this entire process will get thrown out. Everything here is so illegal and unconstitutional and violates every legal principle that, once there is rule of law, everything will get thrown out and it will not be sustainable. So, Yunus cannot touch my mother, and he cannot do anything to her. ”Launching a sharp attack on Bangladesh’s extradition request, Sajeeb Wazed thanked India for protecting Hasina’s life.He also reacted to calls for Yunus’ Nobel Peace Prize to be revoked amid allegations of rights abuses under the interim administration. “Well, Nobel committees never take back their prizes. But look at Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi in Myanmar. She won the Nobel Prize as well. The Peace Prize is basically given by lobbying. But she led to Rohingyas getting killed, and now Yunus is turning Bangladesh into a failed state and an Islamist terrorist state,” he said.Asked what the Congress party in India might have done if it had been in power, the Indian-origin politician replied: “The Congress party would have done the exact same thing that the present government has done. In India, there is rule of law and you have constitutional process. You people have always followed the Constitution and laws.”Wazed sharply criticised the trial process that ended in Hasina’s death sentence, calling it entirely illegal. “This has been done completely illegally. It’s a mockery. First of all, there is a government that is unelected, unconstitutional, and illegal. Then, in order to fast-track the trial in the tribunals, they had to amend laws, which you can only amend with a Parliament. Currently, there is no Parliament. So the process itself was completely illegal. They terminated 17 judges on this tribunal and appointed a new judge who has no experience. He has publicly made a nasty comment about my mother. So he is clearly biased.”He accused authorities of denying Hasina her right to legal representation. “They have not allowed my mother to appoint any lawyer. They appointed their own lawyers to defend my mother. In the history of Bangladesh, such trials take years of hearings, but they completed this in 140 days. So, it’s a complete mockery of justice. There has been no due process. This is a joke,” he added.The ruling marks one of the most consequential legal decisions against a former Bangladeshi leader in decades and comes months before national elections expected in early February. Hasina, 78, has refused to return from India for the trial. The court examined allegations that she ordered a violent response to the mass student uprising that eventually forced her out of power in August 2024.The former prime minister -- Bangladesh’s longest-serving leader -- is facing multiple charges stemming from the period of unrest. A UN rights office report estimated that up to 1,400 people were killed between July 15 and August 15 during the “July Uprising,” which followed a sweeping security crackdown ordered by her government.
Article Summary: Sheikh Hasina's son Sajeeb Wazed slams interim leader Muhammad Yunus. Wazed: Yunus cannot touch my mother and he cannot do anything to her. Accuses authorities of denying Hasina her right to legal representation. Launches attack on Bangladesh’s extradition request.

Article Title: Nepal Gen-Z protest: Fresh clashes in Bara, Simara as tensions escalated for 2nd day; curfew imposed
Article Text:

Nepal Gen Z Protest EXPLODES For 2nd Time, Curfew Imposed, Cops Use LETHAL Force | Watch





Gen Z demonstrators returned to the streets of Nepal’s Bara district on Thursday, reigniting tensions for a second straight day as clashes with police broke out early in the morning.With unrest intensifying in Simara, local authorities imposed a curfew from 1.00 pm to 8.00 pm (local time) in an effort to contain the situation after Wednesday’s confrontation between the youths and CPN-UML cadres."Curfew has been reimposed following the clash with the police to bring the situation under control," assistant chief district officer Chhabiraman Subedi was quoted as saying by ANI.Tensions in Bara have been escalating since Wednesday, after UML (Unified Marxist Leninist) leaders prepared to visit the district ahead of the March 5, 2026 elections. The unrest has raised concerns among experts, who point to the fragile security situation, with hundreds of inmates still at large and a comparable number of weapons missing following the September uprising.The situation intensified when Gen Z supporters were injured in a confrontation at Simara Chowk near the airport, prompting the group to file a complaint against six UML cadres.Gen Z leader Samrat Upadhyay, 21, a resident of Simara in Bara, said that a group of 10–12 youths had gathered peacefully when CPN-UML cadres allegedly attacked them, leaving seven injured, including himself."Thus, our demand is simple – arrest Mahesh Basnet and UML cadres who launched a brutal attack on us today, injuring at least seven of us. Bara will remain close until our demands are met," Upadhyay was quoted as saying by The Himalayan Times.Police later detained Ward Chair Dhan Bahadur Shrestha of Ward 2 and Ward Chair Kaimudin Ansari of Ward 6 of Jeetpursimara Sub-metropolitan City in connection with the earlier clashes.As violence escalated near Simara Airport, police fired tear gas to disperse protestors, leading authorities to temporarily suspend airport operations.The agitated Gen Z protesters have accused the police of failing to apprehend those named in their complaint related to Wednesday’s clash. Sushila Karki , the former chief justice now serving as interim prime minister following the September uprising, urged all political actors to “refrain from unwanted political provocation” and place their trust in the democratic process ahead of the March 5, 2026 elections.In a statement issued late Wednesday, Karki said, “I have directed the Home Administration and security agencies to work with utmost restraint and preparation to maintain peace and order.”She added that her priority is to “ensure the safe movement of leaders of all political parties, and create a fair and fear-free environment for the elections.”Nepal remains in a fragile political transition following the September regime change, when nationwide protests forced then–prime minister and UML chairman KP Oli to resign.The two-day uprising left 76 people dead across the country. What began as anger over a government-imposed social media ban quickly expanded into a wider revolt driven by years of economic stagnation and entrenched corruption in the nation of 30 million.Demonstrators torched parliament, courts and government offices, ultimately toppling the 73-year-old four-time premier. Karki, also 73, was appointed interim prime minister to guide the country toward fresh elections.

Article Title: Verdict in absentia, empathy in short supply: Reading Bangladesh through its Hasina coverage
Article Text:
Ousted Bangladesh PM Hasina Calls ICT’s Death Sentence ‘Rigged’, Says It Denied Fair Trial Rights

Prothom Alo

The Daily Star

bdnews24.com

Bangladesh Pratidin

Naya Diganta

Yugantar

Amader Shomoy





'A good newspaper, I suppose, is a nation talking to itself.' That is how Arthur Miller, eminent US playwright and, incidentally, Marilyn Monroe’s husband for a few turbulent years, defined journalism’s role. Whenever a landmark event hits a country, it is worth listening closely to how the media is reporting it, not just to what is being said, but to what is being left unsaid, either out of compulsion or because it suits the prevailing mood. Political scientist Bernard Cohen once said that the press may not be successful much of the time in telling people what to think, but it is stunningly successful in telling its readers what to think about. Omission, in other words, is a pertinent editorial decision.Seen through that lens, Bangladeshi newspapers and news websites after former prime minister Sheikh Hasina ’s death sentence order reveal a clear pattern. Most outlets have avoided a sharply critical editorial line, the kind that often comes with flowery banner headlines, and have instead stuck to a largely matter-of-fact style. But even this dispassionate tone cannot hide one central truth: there is very little empathy for Hasina across the spectrum.Almost no one seriously interrogates her claim that a 'rigged' tribunal acted in a 'biased' and 'politically motivated' way. Not much space is given to highlight the then ruling Awami League’s version of what went wrong in the handling of the 2024 mass protests, which became a swirling inferno of grievance against the Hasina government and finally led to her ouster.International Crimes Tribunal-1 has sentenced Hasina and former home minister Asaduzzaman Khan Kamal to death for alleged crimes against humanity during the 2024 uprising, in which around 1,400 protesters are believed to have been killed. Former police chief Chowdhury Abdullah Al-Mamun, who turned approver, has received five years’ imprisonment. The first day’s coverage focused on the nuts and bolts of the verdict and reactions from political parties and victims’ families. Subsequently there has been analysis about the future, or lack of it, of Hasina’s party, the Awami League. Reactions from Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International have been prominently carried across newspapers. India’s role has come in for critical assessment, with an almost resigned acceptance that New Delhi is unlikely to extradite Hasina back to Dhaka., probably the country’s best-known newspaper, has depicted Hasina through page-one cartoons on two successive days (18 and 19 November), perhaps to double down on the fact that the verdict was given in absentia, with Hasina and her former home minister Kamal both living in India. It has also carried a detailed ledger of isolated skirmishes and vandalism that had taken place across the country in the run-up to the verdict. On the 19th, Prothom Alo’s front-page lead screams about how Sheikh Hasina is absolutely unrepentant; the sharp wording makes its editorial stance fairly obvious. In its English edition, the paper’s editorial line is explicit: Hasina’s conviction is welcomed as proof that no one, not even a former prime minister, is above the law.moves in similar alleys through its opinion pages. A widely read online piece calls the ruling a historic verdict that still has full moral force despite being delivered in absentia. It describes the judgment as 'personal' and 'overdue', argues that the 'moral ledger has been balanced', and adds that accountability, even if delayed, restores a sense of moral order and confirms that cruelty leaves traces which the world cannot ignore indefinitely. The Daily Star’s own editorial brands the verdict 'inevitable', hopes it offers some closure to the victims and presses the tribunal to remain transparent and rigorous.turns quickly to the organisational shock inside the Awami League. Noting the irony of the tribunal created by Hasina herself to try the 1971 war criminals now delivering a verdict against her, the article claims that the Awami League is facing its deepest crisis in fifty years. While the party nearly splintered after Mujib’s assassination, this time, with its registration suspended, it has its task cut out. The article says Awami League leaders are virtually working from the political underground to keep the flame alive. However, it argues that it is unlikely the Awami League will move on from Hasina, even though the political cost of remaining tied to her name remains high. Hasina is portrayed as both a political liability and irreplaceable glue.chooses to anchor its coverage around Chief Adviser Muhammad Yunus and the interim regime. It highlights what it calls his three priorities: institutional reform, justice for the July killings and a peaceful election. It expresses hope that the February 2026 polls are held on time so that Yunus can 'sign off on a high'. It also flags the next major crimes-against-humanity case in the ICT pipeline, signalling that this verdict is one of many likely to further damage the Awami League’s future.too uses an unflattering cartoon and reports that Bangladesh will send a conviction warrant to Interpol to try to bring her back. It notes three similar cases still pending against her at the tribunal. Its editorial expresses hope that India will hand back Hasina and Kamal under 'international law and protocol'. A detailed piece describes how the verdict has crushed the morale of Awami cadres and affiliates. Many expected massive street protests; instead, they have been muted, the paper argues, because no one wants to expose themselves to the wrath of the authorities when the top leadership is absent or in hiding. An earlier front-page story on 18 November talks about magistrates who allegedly ordered security forces to open fire and are now, according to the paper, comfortably working under the chief adviser; a reminder that the system can punish one figure while quietly absorbing others.looks beyond the verdict and asks who might succeed Hasina within the Awami League. Its analysis names three potential leaders, declares the former PM 'politically dead', but concedes there is still electoral space for an Awami-type party. The condition it sets is telling: only a party that apologises and seeks reconciliation can fully return to the mainstream. Hasina’s legacy, in this framing, is not a foundation but a weight her successors would have to deliberately shed.runs a page-one analysis on the shrinking political space of the Awami League. Playing on the party’s boat symbol, it asks how a boat can reach its destination without its boatman. It also argues that India is now in a bind, as shielding Hasina is sending the wrong signal to the international community. However, the article quotes an expert saying that the Awami League can make a comeback if the government formed after the February polls fails to meet public expectations.Two other papers step back from personalities. Kaler Kantho focuses on the fact that Bangladesh has never actually executed a woman, despite hundreds having received death sentences over the decades. Banik Barta zooms out further, placing Hasina among at least 48 heads of state and government worldwide who have received similar verdicts. Some were executed, others fled, many saw their sentences reduced on appeal. Hasina becomes one point in a longer story about how states dispose of their fallen rulers.Taken together, all this makes it clear that the media ecosystem has, in effect, already written off Sheikh Hasina. The tones vary, from cartoons to future leader analyses, but they converge on a common theme: to treat Mujib's daughter's 'guilt' as settled and her political future as closed. Almost no one attempts a serious reconstruction of Hasina’s defence, or revisits the state’s choices during the protests. In Miller’s terms, the nation is talking to itself through its newspapers, and in that conversation, Hasina appears less as a contested figure than as a cautionary one, a name to be processed, apportioned blame to and then moved beyond, while the real argument shifts to who will inherit the political space she once dominated.
Article Summary: Sheikh Hasina and former home minister Asaduzzaman Khan Kamal sentenced to death for alleged crimes against humanity during the 2024 uprising. Former police chief Chowdhury Abdullah Al-Mamun, who turned approver, has received five years' imprisonment.
